Singapura dan Hong Kong Hadapi Resesi, Bisa Berdampak ke RI?
04 Nov 2019, 11:04 by Vadhia Lidyana


Foto: Fauzan Kamil/Tim Infografis

Jakarta - Dua negara tengah menghadapi resesi, yakni Singapura dan Hong Kong. Meski Singapura sendiri belum jatuh ke jurang resesi seperti Hongkong, namun pertumbuhan ekonominya masih rendah dan terancam resesi. Pertumbuhan ekonomi Singapura secara tahunan atau year on year di kuartal III-2019 dibandingkan kuartal III-2018 hanya tumbuh 0,1%. Lantas, bagaimana dampaknya terhadap perekonomian Indonesia?Menurut Direktur Riset Center of Reform on Economics (Core) Indonesia Pieter Abdullah Redjalam, dampak dari hal tersebut terhadap perekonomian Indonesia tak terlalu signifikan. Pasalnya, pertumbuhan ekonomi Indonesia lebih didominasi oleh konsumsi dalam negeri dan juga pertumbuhan investasi. Sedangkan, pertumbuhan ekspor sendiri sedikit andilnya terhadap pertumbuhan ekonomi. Sehingga, perekonomian Indonesia masih mampu menghadapi berbagai gejolak ekonomi luar negeri."Perekonomian kita kan tidak bergantung ekspor. Kontribusi ekspor ke perekonomian kita relatif kecil. Ekonomi kita lebih bergantung pada isu domestik, dari pertumbuhan konsumsi dan investasi, bukan dari ekspor. Oleh karena itu dampak perekonomian global lebih kecil walaupun kita sudah mengalami pertumbuhan ekspor yang negatif. Kontraksi di ekspor sudah cukup lama, tapi kita bisa tumbuh 5%," jelas Piter kepada detikcom, Senin (4/11/2019). Lalu, untuk Hong Kong sendiri yang sudah terjun ke jurang resesi apakah akan mengancam nasib Tenaga Kerja Indonesia (TKI) di sana? Apalagi TKI punya peran mencetak devisa negara.Menjawab hal tersebut, Piter menuturkan, sebagian besar TKI yang dikirim ke Hong Kong bekerja sebagai asisten rumah tangga (ART). Ia menuturkan, resesi yang disebabkan oleh demonstrasi berlarut-larut ini tak begitu berpengaruh pada orang-orang berpendapatan tinggi di Hong Kong. Sehingga, ART masih akan terus dibutuhkan."TKI banyak ke sana utamanya kan ART, bukan TKI pabrik, bukan tenaga sipil, sehingga kondisinya kembalikan ke kita. Kondisi kita sulit pun ART tetap saja kan. Jadi dampaknya menurut saya terhadap TKI itu sangat minimal. Walaupun resesi di sana, orang-orang kaya di sana masih punya uang, jadi masih butuh ART," ujar Piter.Perlu diketahui, tahun ini ada sekitar 250.000 TKI di Hong Kong. TKI punya andil terhadap devisa negara pasalnya jasa pengiriman uang alias remitansi TKI menyumbang 10% nilai APBN.Kemudian, bagaimana dengan dampak resesi tersebut terhadap perdagangan antara Indonesia dengan Hong Kong?Menurut Piter, hubungan perdagangan Indonesia dengan Hong Kong relatif kecil. Ia mengungkapkan, andil resesi Hong Kong terhadap perdagangannya dengan Indonesia tak begitu besar. "Hubungan dagang kita lebih besar dengan China, Amerika, Eropa, bukan dengan Hong Kong. Terhadap perdagangan dampaknya nggak begitu besar," imbuh dia. Melihat catatan detikcom, hubungan dagang Indonesia dan Hong Kong relatif kecil dibanding negara ASEAN lain. Namun, sejak tahun 2009-2017 neraca dagang antara Indonesia dan Hong Kong selalu surplus. Adapun komoditas terbesar yang diekspor Indonesia ke Hong Kong adalah batu bara, perhiasan, emas, elektronik, dan produk perikanan. Singapore and Hong Kong Face Recession, Can It Affect Indonesia?
04 Nov 2019, 11:04 by Vadhia Lidyana


Photo: Fauzan Kamil / Infographic Team

Jakarta - Two countries are facing a recession, namely Singapore and Hong Kong. Although Singapore itself has not yet fallen into recession like Hong Kong, its economic growth is still low and threatened with recession. Singapore's economic growth on an annual basis or year on year in the third quarter-2019 compared to the third quarter-2018 only grew 0.1%. So, how will this impact on the Indonesian economy? According to Indonesian Center for Reform on Economics (Core) Research Director Pieter Abdullah Redjalam, the impact of this on the Indonesian economy is not too significant. The reason is that Indonesia's economic growth is more dominated by domestic consumption and investment growth. Meanwhile, export growth alone contributed little to economic growth. Thus, the Indonesian economy is still able to deal with a variety of foreign economic turmoil. "Our economy does not depend on exports. The contribution of exports to our economy is relatively small. Our economy is more dependent on domestic issues, from consumption and investment growth, not from exports. Therefore the impact of the global economy is smaller even though we have experienced negative export growth. The contraction in exports is long enough, but we can grow 5%, "Piter explained to AFP on Monday (11/04/2019). Then, for Hong Kong itself that has plunged into recession will threaten the fate of Indonesian Workers (TKI) there? Moreover, migrant workers have the role of printing the country's foreign exchange. Answering this, Piter said, the majority of migrant workers sent to Hong Kong work as household assistants (ART). He said, the recession caused by protracted demonstrations had little effect on high-income people in Hong Kong. So, ART will continue to be needed. "Many migrant workers go there, especially ART, not factory workers, not civil servants, so the conditions return to us. Our conditions are difficult even if ART still remains. So the impact in my opinion on TKI is very minimal. Despite the recession there, rich people there still have money, so they still need ART, "said Piter. It should be known, this year there are around 250,000 migrant workers in Hong Kong. Migrant workers have a stake in the country's foreign exchange because remittance services, aka remittances, migrants contribute 10% of the value of the state budget. Then, what about the impact of the recession on trade between Indonesia and Hong Kong? According to Piter, Indonesia's trade relations with Hong Kong are relatively small. He revealed, the contribution of the Hong Kong recession to trade with Indonesia is not so big. "Our trade relations are bigger with China, America, Europe, not Hong Kong. The impact on trade is not so big," he added. Looking at the AFP record, trade relations between Indonesia and Hong Kong are relatively small compared to other ASEAN countries. However, since 2009-2017 the trade balance between Indonesia and Hong Kong has always been a surplus. The biggest commodities exported by Indonesia to Hong Kong are coal, jewelry, gold, electronics, and fishery products.
